title: It could be more important than ever for students to vote
text:
Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson are likely to be trying to get the student vote (Picture: Getty)

The student vote could be a deciding factor in a number of key marginal constituencies.

The arguing over the date was, in part, due to whether or not students would be able to cast their ballots.

Most higher education terms end on Friday December 13 – the day after the election.

So it is not unreasonable to think that many students (and staff) will be packing up, meeting last-minute deadlines, travelling or even out partying.

Put simply – their minds might not be on the General Election.

Students at Canterbury University managed to swing the vote towards Labour at the last election (Picture: PA)

In the 2017 General Election, some seats appeared to have been swung by students.

In Canterbury, a well-organised student vote saw Labour win the normally safe Conservative seat in Kent with a 20% swing.

Understandably, then, the Tories were pushing for a later date while the Lib Dems, Labour and SNP – parties who traditionally do well with younger voters – wanted to bring the date forward to December 9.

Students can register to vote in their home or university constituencies or even both.

However, they can only vote in one.

Jeremy Corbyn’s supporters are planning to target the student votes (Picture: EPA)

Jeremy Corbyn support group, Momentum, has launched an app that tells a student where to vote in order to most benefit Labour.

Boris Johnson could face a tough challenge as he only has a majority of around 5,000.

There are 10,000 staff and students at Brunel University in his west London constituency and so close attention will be paid.

The tightest race for a university seat (Keele) is Newcastle-under-Lyme, held by Labour by only 30 votes.

Southampton Itchen (Solent) is held by the Tories by 31 votes.

Boris Johnson faces a battle to retain his seat (Picture: EPA)

Analysis shows though that Labour should not assume they have the student vote sewn-up.

Many students will have been too young to vote in the 2016 EU referendum and may favour a party with a clearer strategy on Brexit.

New data published on Tuesday by the polling firm YouthSight shows Labour up to 43% among students, from 38% in the summer.

The Liberal Democrats, who suffered after Nick Clegg’s U-turn on tuition fees, are now at 22%.

The Greens are on 14% while the Conservatives have slipped down to 11%.

The Brexit party is 3% and the SNP are on 2%, Plaid Cymru, DUP and Sinn Fein on 1%.

Students are also likely to keep a close eye on what sweeteners may be offered, such as Theresa May’s previous pledge to cut tuition fees in England to £7,500.
